transcription.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
I kind of would like to share with you
some ideas about the ecosystem development in general,
about how you can take different people together,
align them under some vision, do some great stuff,
and how to build capacity, how to resolve conflicts,
how to deal with the crisis and try
to show it in the few case studies.
So when I just joined, what did I see?
Initially, I was mostly working in development,
so I was specifically following my narrow field.
But when I started to look at the country in general,
I learned that first of all, Ukraine
has one of the best adoption rates and for specific reasons.
Like, we don't have securities market,
people don't trust banks, and so on.
But in the same way, the current situation
is in many countries is quite like raison.
And since 2012 or 14, there were a bunch of tries
to propose some kind of legislation
or something that would guide this industry.
But all of them failed, basically,
before this new president came, like Zelensky,
and he had this vision of a country in a smartphone,
a government in a smartphone.
And they created this ministry, which
consisted mostly of the business people,
young people, which was contrasting a lot
with other other ministries and bodies.
So I started to work there, and what I learned
is basically we can propose something,
but in order to pass anything, we need general consensus.
And at that time, now it's getting much better.
But at that time, most people knew crypto for money laundering,
like drugs and hacks and stuff like that.
So it was like, we needed to come and speak to everybody
and explain this only small percent of it.
Like, dollar is also used for the same purposes.
It doesn't mean we need to burn it.
So in order to make this happen,
I saw some specific problems or challenges.
First of all, every ministry, everybody, or every business,
they had their own agenda.
They saw what they want to do.
The national bank just sees the currency aspect of it.
And somebody is just looking at the exchange market,
on the mining market, but not all of that together.
There was no specific vision of how that all will strive.
And also, another part is the businesses
under like web through crowd is mostly like crypto and ARKIC.
And they hate government.
They don't want to even touch it.
And I feel it.
Same.
But also, there was no productive dialogue, you know?
No attempts to build this connection.
And also, most of the like, this wholly worse,
you know, about like somebody wants to do something
in a position and all this fighting happened inside of Ukraine.
Nobody thought, wow, this is like a global movement.
You know, how do we become competitive like worldwide?
Or how do we think about it as like, not just inside,
but as general?
And the final problem was that was a middle of the bear market.
So it was really hard to find any resources to develop it.
But even like, to illustrate it on the case,
even like with a project that really got funding, you know,
like most of them didn't.
But there was this project.
But the Ministry was developing, like,
it passed the law on what is virtual assets,
basically a crypto, you know, like what is the key,
what is the wallet, stuff like that.
And there was a norm that all of the service providers
need to be in some kind of register.
So we should have some exchanges or brokers,
like their licenses registered somewhere.
And we got this task and this funding from the Swiss embassy.
Yeah, please develop.
It's a nice stuff, you know, like develop this registry.
It got super experienced, the consultants.
They proposed us with three options.
So one is like fully public system, probably on Ethereum,
but maybe something, even whatever.
But then hybrid solution, you know, semi-closed and centralized.
And they did a comparison, a button squirt, you know,
like on the security cost of support, the anti-
like corruption effect and stuff like that.
And altogether, like the Ethereum solution,
the public solution was winning, you know,
and they said, like, we propose this solution.
And I was like, yes, let's do that.
But we needed to consult with other stakeholders.
And the donors who sponsored that, like,
ask them what do they think?
And they said, well, you would probably have 200 companies.
Do you really need blockchain for this, you know?
And then we talked to the businesses, like,
hey guys, what do you think we should build?
And they said, could you just do no registration at all?
Or we will take our business elsewhere, you know,
to other jurisdictions, you don't want to be registered at all.
You know, and the final, like, kill of this idea was from the lawyers.
They said, well, potentially we could use the blockchain here.
But due to the current loss,
all the information should be stored on the servers in the country.
So if you would like to do that, you need to change this.
And that can be like a five-year project, you know,
compared to this small case of, like,
you wanted to do in a half-year.
So guess which solution we preferred?
And that's like the illustration for what I have to deal with.
So that's what led me to think more about the vision, you know?
How do we create, like, even, of course, I see the point,
like, it doesn't make sense to do a 200 people registry
or company registry on the blockchain.
But it's just a start, you know, somebody needs to do this change
in the norm.
Somebody needs to start building different services and information.
It's kind of an open ecosystem and stuff like that.
But nobody stated that as a task.
You know, we just solved this small solution here and there.
So I was in the search for the vision.
And one of my friends from the UNDP acceleration lab,
he recommended to use the foresight.
And basically, the foresight is there, like,
it's a research method.
It's the community development approach.
It's, like, really hard to tell in just few words.
But what it isn't, for sure, it's not a prediction.
You know, it's not about, like, OK, last year we earned $1 million.
So next year, maybe it's $2 million.
It's rather about the different trends that can occur
and how, like, they can play out together.
You know, what happens if all of them materialize
or none of them materialize?
What then would happen?
Who will win?
And so on.
So one of the key ideas is that it should be, like,
systematic and participatory.
So for that, we took each of a kind.
We took representatives from every ministry, you know,
from National Bank to Cyber Police.
We took parliamentaries, every kind of business, social,
NGOs, economists.
I would even like ecologists, you know,
because that was also one of the insights there.
And we got them together in a set of, like, offline events
and Zoom calls to speak about what do they see,
what trends do they see, what future or, like, what needs do they have.
And the second aspect of it is, like, we gathered all of that intelligence
about the future for our long-term vision process.
So we said, like, it's not for a year.
It's, like, 20, 30, you know, 10 years.
For many people in the ministry planning for 10 years,
it was, like, can't do.
But we strive for that.
And the two key trends that we identified
was, like, first of all, the asset tokenization, you know,
whether it would grow or not, and control our personality.
And in the-- our audience, nobody believed that it won't grow.
Everybody believed it would grow, you know?
So we didn't even consider those scenarios.
But where the real fight happened is in the between this personality control.
So mostly people spoke about, on the one hand, the values of the security,
you know, protection of, like, customers, consumers, and so on.
But on the other hand, it's like freedom, you know?
No protection.
We can lose our, like, freedom.
But that doesn't mean that we'll have gained protection, for sure, you know?
So at one moment, we just stand it on the line, you know, from the, like,
security to freedom.
And people stated some arguments.
And other could, you know, change the place at this.
And we ended up, you know, like, somewhere in the middle,
but closer to the freedom.
And the scenario, what the metaphor for this scenario,
we call it digital Venice, in a way of, like, golden age of trade, you know,
open trade and prosperity, lots of bridges between all of these systems and so on.
In comparison to digital dictatorship, you know, where mass surveillance,
of course, some maybe big enterprises can win, you know?
But for the innovation, for the consumers and so on, it doesn't prove to be the best.
So this was our, like, choice there.
And after that, what initially happened is people started to, like,
they saw all of that community gathered around us, ideas,
and they started to propose different projects.
You know, we started to see, like, who's going to need to do what, you know?
What governments needs to do, what businesses needs to do, you know,
that set up the initial roadmap of our operations,
where people really proposed something, what they wanted.
And by the end of, like, this six months, extensive work, I was super happy.
And I was like, I saw a lot of stakeholders, we established all these contacts,
we had this developmental vision, we had this roadmap, 70 pages,
report, extensive, you know, education happened through this, you know,
people discussed, you know, like, in national, but what is DeFi,
what is NFT and stuff like that.
But one of the key ideas is that people built trust, you know,
I heard somebody telling, like, from the business,
"Oh, this guy from the financial monitoring, he's, like, adequate and nice, you know,
we can probably speak to him."
And government also, like, governmental workers, they had, like,
"Okay, these founders, entrepreneurs, they're, like, okay, they do some nice stuff."
So it created the initial basis for, like, human relations in this process.
And we also established the project office, you know, with all these experts,
11 working groups, some of them already got funding for education and infrastructure.
And I was, like, on the high moment of it at that time.
And what you could think is what can go wrong, you know, after that.
Well, on February 24, the day that most of Ukrainians will remember for long, you know,
the world started.
And now, after eight months, it's kind of, like, a new normality, you can say.
But the first months, I felt, like, would I really, like, would I have to speak to,
like, speaking to my close one?
Would I have a chance to speak to him tomorrow?
I wasn't sure.
And all of this nice development of plans, they were also doomed, you know,
who will think about this innovation at this time.
So this was also, like, I recognized the moment we recognized in our team
that we can't also lower hands, you know,
this time required us to act and to do something.
And what was promising really is that on the base of the initial trust
that people, you know, are talking together, a bunch of projects emerged
that started to, you know, collect funding.
And one of such projects is called "Date for Ukraine."
It was under the Ministry of Digital Transformation Brand.
And supported by a few businesses, you know.
So, go, Amanda, start this crypto and send it to the different purchases.
The key idea there was that the supply chain requirements were super high.
If there would be need, like, quadrocopter or, you know, a car,
you would need it tomorrow, you know.
So you don't have time to do this bureaucratic procedures or whatever.
So it's been another process a lot.
And the transparency of it.
And, yeah, that was one of the biggest ones,
which collected around 60 million dollars from 50,000 people.
And you could see that Ethereum ecosystem played a big role,
as well as, like, people donated around 300 dollars,
but guys like Vitalik Buterian, like, in millions and so on.
So feel free to check it out.
And the other, like, projects were initiated by a set of, like, business owners.
They said, like, under our reputation, we collect these funds.
And it was, like, important at the time many people,
like, not only good actors activated, but bad actors activated,
where they collected, like, kind of, for Ukraine, you know,
but could, you know, just take this money.
So the brand of ministry or the brand of, like, business owners and so on
was really important for that.
And, like, and chain fund, they had the small multi-seag, you know,
they, like, we didn't have the time to build a full-scale, you know,
down for everything, but we tried to keep the closest to that.
And you can see that the money was sent, like, for different causes.
We need to, like, be lean and agile.
There was many grassroots, you know, initiatives that needed just small amounts of funds.
So there was, like, these people struggling in the other countries,
migration, that they had no money to survive, you know,
and they can't even always use their money for some reason.
So this help card, direct given, was also major thing.
And finally, NFTs, NFTs became, like, a real thing.
Ukraine, the other, like, one of the major, they collected, like,
more than six million, and they decided to distribute those funds
across the, like, trusted NGOs, because, like, from the external view,
you don't know, like, who do they need to, you know, like,
we don't respect too much, guys, like, Red Cross or somebody,
because they don't go this last mile to the real, you know, like,
workplace and to help those people.
So the, like, and for external, they don't know where to give.
So they kind of created this connection, or the Museum of War,
which connected both the aspect of, like, creativity to the fundraising for the ministry.
We even got this crypto bank, we sold for 100k.
So first of all, I would like to thank you a lot for, as a community,
for everybody who supported it, who donated, who tracked, who was with us
in this hard moment.
After this, you know, nobody can say in Ukraine that,
in crypto, it's, like, non-desirable or something.
So, yeah, just for this moment, thank you.
[APPLAUSE]
Thank you so much, my--
No, it's not total.

Sorry.
Do I have time?
Yeah, I have some time.
I'm a finishing, sorry.

So what I propose to, like, what we can do next is, like,
like, let's keep hacking, you know, like, currently the, like,
we got bombed all the time, you know, now they, like, aim at the,
like, electrical and, like, water infrastructure and so on.
But that doesn't stop people from, like, coding and doing their work,
you know, the work, like, in the underground or whatever.
They keep hacking just recently.
There was, like, a hackathon in Kiev where Vitalik was.
And people were, like, thinking about the solution that can be just,
like, now we need it in Ukraine.
But tomorrow, you know, who knows which country.
Already, like, if you look at the security aspect of the DLT,
like in Georgia or Taiwan, they already are thinking about the cyber attacks
that can happen.
And in our country, it's also, like, quite a big problem.
And it's also a bunch of migration challenges,
because, of course, like, national banks, they try to, like, secure macro situation,
you know, but also people can't always, you know, transfer money or, like,
open the bank account.
And in our region, we're looking to move all of this ownership-right system
to the trusted ecosystems.
And just, like, as a final note, what I learned through all of this experience,
you know, what I hope you can use in your work as well,
is that without the vision, you know, that won't work, you know,
we'll be still disconnected in what we do.
And what we achieved is, like, the sense of the shared future
and the community who was, like, experienced this shared future,
is, like, in the world, we all became kind of a doll.
Like, everybody started to work despite any conflict.
And second is that, well, while technology can be noitral, in a way, you know,
like, but with the same technology, you can build either dictatorship or, like,
Venice, whatever, like, democracy.
So, and for that, there should be a demand, like, understanding from the people,
like, currently, it's just, you know, a few percent, one percent.
You know, we need more people to really kind of request it from the politicians
and politicians that move it.
It's kind of a long process, but without this, like,
we in the wind interaction and consents, consences, it just won't happen.
And in our approach, we saw that raising awareness and education was key, you know,
people just, if they don't get it, they don't trust it.
So, currently, we're launching a program to get, like,
by 2030, more than half of Ukrainian script to literate.
And we're now educating our mental workers how to use metamask and stuff like that.
So, they will have practical skills, they will see it.
So, that would really help us in the, like, or everybody helping the crisis.
So, people will already rely and know that.
So, on that note, thank you again.
Let's connect. You have an ally in the Ukrainian government, in me.
If you want to do something together, please find me or connect.
I will be really happy to help.
Thank you.
